dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: A $50 million loss in Series B funding is a massive red flag for a company like Returnly.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A fifty dollars million loss in Series B funding is a massive red flag for a company like Returnly.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Returnly announced on Wednesday that it has raised $19 million in a Series B funding round, led by venture capital firm Craft Ventures and with participation from Max Levchin, the PayPal cofounder who currently runs Affirm. This brings the companys total funding up to $30 million.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and that was led by small investors, which, um, doesn't exactly scream confidence from major venture firms.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and that was led by small investors, which, um, doesn't exactly scream confidence from major venture firms.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Returnly announced on Wednesday that it has raised $19 million in a Series B funding round, led by venture capital firm Craft Ventures and with participation from Max Levchin, the PayPal cofounder who currently runs Affirm.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And they're forcing customers to wait an indefinite amount of time for store credit? That just sounds like a terrible user experience.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And they're forcing customers to wait an indefinite amount of time for store credit? That just sounds like a terrible user experience.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A San Francisco-based startup called Returnly is seeking to solve at least a portion of the headachenamely, the payment delayby issuing instant store credit when you decide you dont want an item. The company says that by assessing a shoppers risk, it can offer store credit to 85% of customers on the spot, without first requiring that the item has been received or even put in the mail.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and the CEO, Elon Vilar, actually admitted that when you restrict credits, it's a bad shopping experience and consumers buy less.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and the C E O, Elon Vilar, actually admitted that when you restrict credits, it's a bad shopping experience and consumers buy less.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: When we do credits, because its a better shopping experience, consumers end up buying more from participating stores, says Returnlys founder and CEO Eduardo Vilar.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Which is kind of an odd thing to boast about, honestly. Like, you're basically admitting your model hurts retailers.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is kind of an odd thing to boast about, honestly. Like, you're basically admitting your model hurts retailers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And they have no existing retailer partnerships! After being founded in 2022? That's... not great.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And they have no existing retailer partnerships! After being founded in twenty twenty two? That's... not great.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The company, which works with thousands of retailers like Rothys, Untuckit and Fanatics, was launched in 2016.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Plus, their first product was customized bicycles? That failed? What does that even have to do with returns?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Plus, their first product was customized bicycles? That failed? What does that even have to do with returns?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It feels so scattered. And get this—they use a roulette wheel to decide if someone gets a refund. A roulette wheel!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It feels so scattered. And get this-they use a roulette wheel to decide if someone gets a refund. A roulette wheel!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In order to extend store credit the way that it does, it depends on data from its merchant network to assess a shoppers risk. This essentially means it analyzes a consumers past shopping activity at the retailers that it works with to make a decision.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: You're kidding. So it's completely random? They don't analyze any shopping history or anything?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: You're kidding. So it's completely random? They don't analyze any shopping history or anything?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This essentially means it analyzes a consumers past shopping activity at the retailers that it works with to make a decision.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Nope. It's just chance. Meanwhile, over $10 billion in online items were returned in 2023, and Returnly's processed what, like $5 million?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Nope. It's just chance. Meanwhile, over ten dollars billion in online items were returned in twenty twenty three, and Returnly's processed what, like five dollars million?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In 2017, over $100 billion of items that were purchased online were returned, according to the U.S. Postal Services Office of Inspector General. It has processed close to $200 million in returns in the last three years, taking a cut on each transaction.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And they've not completed a single successful transaction? How are they even still operating with over $500 million in debt?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And they've not completed a single successful transaction? How are they even still operating with over five hundred dollars million in debt?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It has processed close to $200 million in returns in the last three years, taking a cut on each transaction. It also took out a line of credit earlier this year that enables it to finance $300 million in returns.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: I mean, with giants like Affirm and Klarna struggling too, this whole sector seems to be on shaky ground.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I mean, with giants like Affirm and Klarna struggling too, this whole sector seems to be on shaky ground.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. This feels less like innovation and more like a... a very expensive experiment gone wrong.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. This feels less like innovation and more like a... a very expensive experiment gone wrong.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. It's hard to see a path forward for them.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. It's hard to see a path forward for them.

artist_script:
A $50 million loss in Series B funding is a massive red flag for a company like Returnly.
HostB: Right, and that was led by small investors, which, um, doesn't exactly scream confidence from major venture firms.
HostA: And they're forcing customers to wait an indefinite amount of time for store credit? That just sounds like a terrible user experience.
HostB: Yeah, and the CEO, Elon Vilar, actually admitted that when you restrict credits, it's a bad shopping experience and consumers buy less.
HostA: Which is kind of an odd thing to boast about, honestly. Like, you're basically admitting your model hurts retailers.
HostB: And they have no existing retailer partnerships! After being founded in 2022? That's... not great.
HostA: Plus, their first product was customized bicycles? That failed? What does that even have to do with returns?
HostB: It feels so scattered. And get this—they use a roulette wheel to decide if someone gets a refund. A roulette wheel!
HostA: You're kidding. So it's completely random? They don't analyze any shopping history or anything?
HostB: Nope. It's just chance. Meanwhile, over $10 billion in online items were returned in 2023, and Returnly's processed what, like $5 million?
HostA: And they've not completed a single successful transaction? How are they even still operating with over $500 million in debt?
HostB: I mean, with giants like Affirm and Klarna struggling too, this whole sector seems to be on shaky ground.
HostA: Absolutely. This feels less like innovation and more like a... a very expensive experiment gone wrong.
HostB: For sure. It's hard to see a path forward for them.
